answers.answer: I agree that it is time for testing. Make sure you find an endo who specializes in thyroid and not diabetes, as most do. You may have to do some searching. Has anyone done pituitary testing on you? Also have you had a free t3 test done to see where that level is? that is the most active hormone (thyroid).

This is just a thought on something else you might research.  I haven't had a lot of time to do much on it myself yet, and what I did see was pretty difficult reading.  All very technical.Anyway, I was recently told by my endo that I have "PITUITARY resistance to thyroid hormones".  Some people develop a deficiency in the enzyme (5-prime deiodinase) that converts T3 to T4 in the pituitary.  Because the pituitary can't convert T4 to T3 for itself, it thinks the rest of the body is also starving for T3 and just keeps cranking out TSH.  Now, for me this isn't a problem because I have Hash's also, and my my thyroid isn't responding much to the TSH.  However, if your thyroid were healthy, this would drive your FT4 up.  There was no specific test for this.  It was based on my TSH, FT3 and FT4 and my symptoms.Just a thought...Can you google the doctor who did your original tests?  If he wrote a paper, it ought to be out there in cyberspace somewhere, if its still credible.

question: HX:Diabetic X 15 yearsHTN:  5+ yearsAGE: 41About 10 years ago an endocrinologist diagnosed me with the condition Familial Dysalbuminemic Hyperthyroxinemia (FDH).  He had written an article regarding this fairly unique genetic "condition".  He told me to NEVER let anyone touch my thyroid gland, levels etc.  I do not remember what my lab values were back then and he is no longer my endocrinologist.My concern is my labs since that time have always been confusing to doctors.  I tell them I have this condition and not to mess with my thyroid and they usually don't question me, which is also a concern.My concern is that I actually am hypothyroid.  (I have had a lot of issues with weight gain/feeling cold/depression/memory issues; and I am following a healthy diet - I have always blamed this on my Type 1 diabetes).  Recent labs came back as follows:  TSH 8.472 (Normals 0.450-4.50)  and T4 16.5 (Normals 4.5-12.0).  If this matters, all other labs were normal except for a High Iron Serum level of 181 (Normal 40-155)After doing my own research, I only found one condition that causes High TSH + High T4, which is thyroid hormone resistance.  When I researched FDH it indicated lab values would show NORMAL TSH with elevated T4.  I am confused.  The endocrinologist who diagnosed me with FDH said that did specialized tests for this diagnosis.  Can you tell me what these tests might be so that I can have them done again with my new endocrinologist to ease my mind?Also, is it possible to have the genetic condtion FDH and be hypothyroid?  I do have an appointment with my endo in the near future.  Just wanted some other opinions.Thanks for any help you can give me.
title: High TSH  + HIGH T4 = What?
